Hello :slightly_smiling_face:
I'm developing an app for internal company use that uploads a lot of data to a server from tables in the field. Often poor reception and horrendous response times.
This causes a vast array of networking errors. It is however critical that the data arrives at some point.
I'd like to ask if anyone has a decent concept for how this should be ensured.
The server uses a simple REST over https interface.
A little at a time, do it in a service use sync adapters
Does this automatically handle retries etc?
The most common error is 504 Gateway timeout
Which basically translates to a really poor RTT
No
but you can use something like RxAndroid
It has exponential back off for retries
The app is basically a map app with rather specific reporting features. The users can often attempt to send a new (small) package once every few seconds
Plus there's a need to check in with the server often due to a special "coordinate" system. Causing an extra load on the network
I wrote a decent adapter for sending the data, but the issue arises if the user closes the app or it crashes.

> if the user closes the app
that’s why you want to run your transfer in a background service, so you can complete the uploads
Ideally the app should seamlessy attempt to upload, but if the network fails for the entire shift it should store until it hits home office wifi again
crashing is a different story though
Considered sharedpreferences but it doesn't seem thread safe
It doesn't need to be uploaded pronto, but the user needs to be confident that no data is lost. Pretty much the key

you should have an Alarm service which will be trigger when you find wifi or you can also have scheduler which will activate at certain time like when user plug in the charger, connect to wifi, or when network changes etc
this service will do the pending upload task
Optimally whenever it gets a decent RTT from the server
I'm doing a GPSchange-triggered tiny request for the alternative coordinate system
Could do an RTT check on that
Or use GCM Network Task manager
and schedule periodic tasks
Any way to exclude directories from ContentResolver/MediaStore/CursorLoader? or do I just filter the results manually after I get everything.
Thank you guys :slightly_smiling_face: A lot of good resources here!
What is the best way to parse JSON? using android's in build JSONparsing or by using external libraries like GSON / Jackson
GSON/Jackson
Thank you <@U0548MM6B>

Is it a bad practice to keep the `app` context in a static variable? It seems to me like it wouldn’t be, because either the app context exists, or you’re not running anymore.. so it’s not really a leak like keeping an activity stored in a static var.
<@U2D3K2JMA|mahesh> has joined the channel
it’s definitely not a leak
but is not nice :smile:
<@U16GF1B0F> it’s normal, I usually have a singleton that extends Application
I think it is a common practice
Yeah, that’s what I was doing.. but now the linter in AS 2.2 is claiming it’s an issue.. I was disagreeing
cool
however, there are some people that claim using singleton is not a good practice, so it all comes down to your own definition of good code :smile:
glad to know i’m not a terrible programmer :slightly_smiling_face:
(I am not one of those :stuck_out_tongue: )
some people claim node.js is the best thing ever ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
MongoDB is webscale
:joy:
<@U16GF1B0F> if you use a DI framework then you can just have it as a singleton there and inject it wherever you need it
yep, that’s a good thing to do imo
Yeah
It’s still a hard reference that gets kept, and I was just wondering why AS was yelling at me
I have an `ApplicationComponent` which exposes this `@ApplicationContext Context applicationContext();`
how do you access android string resources from presenter layer?
Ideally you don’t, depending on the scenario I would either use the int resId passed to the view or allow the view to set the message from the method purpose

need to set some text to a view based on several conditions. Where should the conditional code be? If it’s in presenter i’ll need context to look up for string resources. Can shift it to view layer but then views should be dumb right and not contain any logic
<@U21MN5Z0R> use value constants
`if (poopHitsTheFan) view.setMessage(TYPE_1)`
Then how to make these constants translatable?
in your view

```
switch(type)
  case TYPE_1:
      return getResources(r.id.message);
```
Constants work better than resId since you’re presenter could then be java
cool let me try this approach. looks good
<@U08GFT5V5> this doesn’t seem to efficient enough for my case. I am converting a minutes string to hours and there are a lot of cases
<@U21MN5Z0R> then it might be something that your view should be doing
hmm but then testing will become difficult
i am thinking of hacking it for just this one case and using constants everywhere else
:stuck_out_tongue:

Hey guys, I am working on a Location Tracking SDK and was facing issues with PeriodicTasks (GCMNetworkManager) where i schedule them for every 60seconds with `NETWORK_STATE_CONNECTED` condition but the OS doesn’t schedule it sometimes for no reason.

Also i have observed that these Periodic Tasks stop firing on certain Low End Android Devices again for no discernible reason. Can anyone help me out with this?

 ```        PeriodicTask.Builder builder = new PeriodicTask.Builder()
                .setService(PostDataGcmTaskService.class)
                .setPeriod(repeatDuration)
                .setRequiredNetwork(Task.NETWORK_STATE_CONNECTED)
                .setRequiresCharging(false)
                .setPersisted(true)
                .setTag(POST_DATA_GCM_PERIODIC_TASKS_TAG)
                .setUpdateCurrent(true);

        GcmNetworkManager.getInstance(context).schedule(builder.build());```

This is how i am initializing the PeriodicTasks.

The first statement in `onRunTask()` of `PostDataGcmTaskService.class` is a log statement which proves the PeriodicTask doesn’t get fired. I ve even handled PlayService/App upgrade using the `onInitializeTasks()` method.
Any help would be appreciated here.
<@U2DD4H4QZ|d_for_real> has joined the channel
<@U2DD5GJ6S|patch> has joined the channel

I got this message from Xavier Ducrohet (Android Tools Lead @ Google) on another Slack group I’m in:

> Attention people,  it has come to our attention that someone uploaded versions of support libraries (24.0, 24.1, 24.2) on jcenter. We are working to remove them but in the mean time Gradle may download them automatically if you don't have the latest m2repo installed. If you want to be sure you are using the official version, you should 1. download the latest m2repo, and 2. delete your `~/.gradle/caches` folder to ensure you don't have these (possibly rogue) versions of support lib.

This is a potential vulnerability for malicious code injection.
<@U0552KSRK> whats that slack group?
<@U04UB14RZ> <https://androidstudygroup.slack.com/> But it’s a private group (need to be nominated from the inside)

According to Xavier:
```
Xavier Ducrohet [9:02 PM]  
he pushed constraint-layout on June 15th
and then support lib on june 26th
```
I actually noticed this a while ago
I tracked down slow dependency resolution to gradle getting android support libs from bintray
yeah on jcenter huh.. maybe that's because google doesn’t use the normal god damn way to push libraries just like they refuse to use the normal way of doing anything else when it comes to android
<@U055GGAHS> agreed, they need to host the support libs on jcenter themselves
would've saved them from this issue as well
they already host the gradle plugin and all the build stuff on jcenter
so
